citation.article-title: Methanolobus zinderi sp. nov., a methylotrophic methanogen isolated from a deep subsurface coal seam.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methanolobus zinderi sp. nov.

Methanolobus zinderi (zin′der.i. N.L. gen. masc. n. zinderi of Zinder, named in honour of Stephen H. Zinder for his outstanding contributions to our understanding of the microbiology and ecology of methanogenesis).
Cells are irregular coccoids, 1.0–2.0 μm in diameter.
Cells grow by forming methane from methanol and methylamines.
Cells are unable to grow with H2/CO2 or acetate.
The maximum rate of growth is between 40–50 °C, 0.2–0.6 M NaCl, 100–≥200 mM MgCl2 and pH 7.0–8.0.
No organic compounds are required for growth.
The type strain, SD1T (=ATCC BAA-1601T=DSM 21339T), was isolated from a coal seam near Monroe, LA, USA.
The G+C content of the genomic DNA of the type strain is 42±1 mol%.
